text: A restaurant supply truck is curbside, near a small  restaurant.  GERALD GRUNICK, forty-one, is closing the ba door of his truck, feeling good about the world, a common state for him.  He moves towards the cab of the truck and inside as we SUPER:
As he sits down beaming over his recent good fortune... n REVEAL his twelve-year-old son, TOM, seated quietly besid He seems a bit down.  Gerald glances at his son.
I don't know a recent Saturday I've sold more.  You didn't think I'd sell that health restaurant, did you?
No.  Not even you.
Why so glum?
I don't know.
(a beat)
Go ahead.
No, nothing.  I've got a problem, I guess.
Were you bothering by those waitresses making a fuss?
No.  But, honest.  What are you supposed to say when they keep talking about your looks?  I don't even know what they mean -- "Beat them off with a stick." Gerald stiffs a grin.
You know, Tom, I feel a little proud when people comment on your looks.  Maybe you should feel that way.
Proud?  I'm just embarrassed that I like when they say those things.
As long as that's your only problem you're...
It's not. He looks directly at his father and talks quietly, and si
I got my report card.  Three Cs, two Ds and an incomplete.
Oh my.  I see you studying so hard, Tom.  What do you think the problem is?
I'll just have to try harder.  I don't  know.  I will. (talking himself into it)
I will.  I will.  I will. He shakes his head for emphasis, glad he's received this talk from himself -- he hands the card to his father.
Thanks, Dad, this talk helped.  Will  you sign it, please?
(as he signs)
Would it help if I got you a tutor?
(suddenly hopeful)
That would be great. (worried)
It better help.  What can you do with yourself if all you do is look good?
AARON ALTMAN, looking almost preposterously young in his graduation gown -- is delivering his valedictory.  He is rare bread -- a battle-scarred innocent.

...and finally to the teachers of Whitman High School, I don't have the words to express my gratitude which may have more to say about the quality  of the English Department here than  my own limitations... He awaits a laugh and gets only the weird sound of collec discomfort.

...that was, of course, not meant to be taken seriously.  A personal note.   I am frequently asked what the special  difficulties are in being graduated  from High School two months shy of my  fifteenth birthday.  I sometimes  think it was the difficulties  themselves which enabled me to do it. If I'd been appreciated or even tolerated I wouldn't have been in such a hurry to graduate.  I hope the next student who comes along and is able to excel isn't made to feel so much an outcast.  But I'm looking forward to college; this is the happiest day I've had in a long time.  I thank you and I forgive you. This is very little applause.
I'm always so confused by Aaron. Is he brave and earnest or just a conceited little dick-head?

head_text.subj: BACK TO AARON AS WE SUPER

text: As Aaron walks to his seat past three full grown tough lo semi-literate high school graduates.
Later, Aaron.
Clusters of graduates at the fence bordering the sunken s yard looking down as the tough cap and gowners seen earli cuff Aaron around.
Aaron feeling from a blow -- his lip bleeding -- his teet covered with blood...as he gets to his feet.  He is livid something primal triggered by this brutality.
Go ahead, Stephen -- take your last licks. (points at his face)

But this will heal -- what I'm going to say to you will scar you forever.  Ready?  Here it is. He dodges as they come after him.  They catch him by the and hurl him to the ground.  As he gets up he hurls his devastating verbal blow.
You'll never make more than nineteen thousand dollars a year. Ha ha ha. They twist his arm and grip him -- his face scraped on th concrete.

Okay, take this:  You'll never leave South Boston and I'm going to see the whole damn world.  You'll never know the pleasure of writing a graceful sentence or having an original thought.  Think about it. He's punched in the stomach and sinks to the ground.  As Young Toughs walk off Aaron catches a phrase of their conversation.
Nineteen thousand dollars... Not bad.

JANE CRAIG, ten years old, is in her room typing.  Above desk where she works is a bulletin board with letters and pictures tacked to each one.  Her desk has several file r which contain bulging but neat stacks of air mail envelop a roll of stamps in a dispenser is to one side.  Jane typ very well in the glare of her desk lamp.
(voice over; as she types)

Dear Felatzia, it's truly amazing to me that we live a world apart and yet have the same favorite music. I loved the picture you sent and have it up on my bulletin board. You're growing so much faster than I am that I...
SHOWING Jane's FATHER standing near the door.
(voice over)
...am starting to get jealous. I read in the newspapers about the Italian strike and riots in Milan.  I hope you weren't...
(softly)
Honey?... Jane SCREAMS, and grabs her heart, breathing heavily, bab nervously at her Dad.

Oh God -- Daddy -- don't...don't... don't ever scare me like that -- please. We SUPER:  "FUTURE NETWORK NEWS PRODUCER" Her father is himself taken aback with the shock of her r Falling back towards the door:
Jane -- For God's sake... (recovering)
Look, it's time for you to go to sleep.
I just have two more pen pals and then I'm done.
You don't have to finish tonight.
(he doesn't get in)
Nooo.  This way the rotation stays the same.
Finish quickly.  I don't want you getting obsessive about these  things.  Good night. We REMAIN WITH Jane who has obviously become disconcerted troubled.

As Jane moves to room at the other end of the hall -- a f room where her Father reads the latest  Rolling Stone of the mid-60's -- Hunter Thompson, the New Journalism, the slim Jann Wenner -- Jane bursts into the room.
Dad, you want me to choose my words so carefully and then you just throw a word like 'obsessive' at me.  Now, unless I'm wrong and... (enunciating)

...please correct me if I am, 'obsession' is practically a psychiatric term... concerning people who don't have anything else but the object of their obsession -- who can't stop and do anything else.  Well, Here I am stopping to tell you this.  Okay? So would you please try and be a little more precise instead of calling a person something like 'obsessive.' She advances furiously on her Father since even this stru even with two additional pen pal letters to get off, she enough sense of duty to kiss him good night before stormi the room.  She exits the room INTO BLACK. Stay on BLACK as we begin MAIN TITLES:

Emerging from the blackness -- Jane Craig -- now a twenty-eight-year-old woman -- a long speed walker wearin jacket to which reflecting stripes have been glued -- the of gear only possessed by someone who runs at off-hours. Jacket itself is a wish-I-had-it souvenir from some impor news assignment, the sort of treasure you love about all yet never mention.  She stops running as she feeds quarte the first of a phalanx of newspaper machines -- getting s different papers before moving on.
As she enters from the bathroom, having showered and dres The sun is jus now rising.  She sits next to her phone.

The Filofax book is almost an additional character -- a c hand-fashioned tool of Jane's trade.  She flicks at a pag takes down a typewritten sheet scotch-taped to it showing room number of her crew and reporter.
As she dials one room number.
(into phone)
Hi...It's me...
ANGLE ON CAMERAMAN -- his equipment in evidence though essentially asleep holding his bedmate's hand, as he list to Jane.
(voice over)
It's thirty minutes before you have to meet me in the lobby -- nudge your wife.
There's probably no time to eat... but there's a cafeteria at the bus depot once we get down there.  I love working with you two...It  saves me a call. She dales.
Where Aaron is switching his TV from station to station, monitoring the early morning news.  His PHONE RINGS.
Hi.  Turn on your TV... Good Morning America , the Morning News and  Today are all about to talk to Arnold  Schwarzenegger and I think he's  live on at least two of them.
At six o'clock on the wake-up news they used the wrong missile graphic.
(Austrian accent)

Now listen, Arnold just said that he's been making three million a movie now.  But he's not ever  gonna change.  He's still the same person when he was making two  million dollars a movie.  He feels no different.  He also bought a brand- new condo with Maria, they gonna furnish tastefully.
A half hour in the lobby.
(Austrian accent)

Okay, I'll see you in the lobbies [ sic ]. She hangs up -- takes the phone off the hook and lays it bed for a moment's solitude.  She sits stiffly, palms on her legs.  It looks like someone with unusually good post waiting for something, and now we BEGIN TO SEE the first redden and she begins to cry.  Now she sobs -- then mirac shakes it off and exits quickly to the bathroom.  This cr episode is clearly part of her morning routine.

Jane standing behind her husband-wife - camera-sound team as they train their attention on Aaron; who is getting re do a stand-up.  There is a DERELICT off to one side.  Aar his microphone at the ready.
Ready.
Your hair's a little funny.
It's an ethnic curl, I can't do anything about it.
In front of a little -- it's a bit... You want a mirror?
No -- Don't worry about it.  Let's do this. Jane nods her assent.
Okay.
In other times, for other purposes, there might be a band and bunting here at the bus depot for J.D. Singer's return from war.  He...
(interrupting)
I'm sorry.  But look at how wonderful his face is. She points to the derelict.
Oh, you mean use him...That's nice.  Okay.
I'll put him in the low corner of the frame -- good.

In other times, with other purposes, there might be a band and bunting here at the bus depot for J.D. Singer's return from war.  Last week he was decorated by a president for heroism in a war.  But it was the civil war -- in Angola -- and he was in it for the money. He puts the microphone down.
Thanks. He passes a vending machine and checks the stray hair.

Jane in the distant b.g. on the phone.  Aaron and crew sh as the bus pulls up, hisses to a stop and tired, rumpled passengers exit the bus.  J.D. SINGER, strong, 9'6" figur emerges and is displeased to find a camera trained on him He reacts with all the grace of a short mercenary.
Go 'way. J.D. gets his luggage from the compartment under the bus. crew shooting.
Just a few questions?
No. He starts walking -- the four person newsteam staying wit
We came from Washington.
Move away from me.
(holding out microphone)
How long has it been since you've been home.
(moving)
Fuck.  Fuck.  Fuck.  Fuckes.  Snot... Fuckee.  You want to use that?
It depends on how big a news day it  is. They reach Jane.  She calls to him.
J.D.  I'm Jane Craig.  I spoke to you in Angola.  I gave you some sugarless gum and Handi-Wipes. As he reacts to her:
Jane sitting next to Aaron making detailed timing notes a screens the material shot that day on a portable monitor
Where's where I asked him about being scared? (then)
You should work on your speech.
No.  It makes me nervous to think about it.  Let's do this. She consults her notes and goes back to the exact spot.
(on tape)
All this business of war -- do you get scared?
(on tape; he smiles)
Uh-uh. (then)
I'm a little freaked right now about seeing my father though. He laughs self-consciously and turns briefly away.
I love that turn away.

Jane is at the lectern in the darkened auditorium as two monitors display some  taped news pieces she has assembled.  On the lectern is a sign telling us we are at the Conference Local Television News Broadcasters.
(in darkness)
There's a point I'm trying to make about these pieces coming up. A WOMAN'S OUTLINE blacked out from behind -- her VOICE ELECTRICALLY DISGUISED.
(o.s.; angrily)
I don't think any client of mine makes less than fifty thousand dollars a year which means they can afford the best and you're damn right I feel good that that includes me.
in blackness, her VOICE DISGUISED.

No.  You'd be surprised at who a working girl meets.  I've been a working girl for what? -- over a year anyway and that must be a thousand men and I don't think there's an age or type that hasn't been in there.
(voice over)
Policemen?  -- Doctor? -- Lawyer...?
Oh, sure.  Television reporters. A laugh from the audience.  There is a:
A WOMAN in blackness.

I'm seventeen now and I've been working the streets for two years and I guess to be honest -- I stopped thinking of it as temporary. The lights come up on the room.  The two screens go black there is general APPLAUSE.  Jane blinks nervously.
Please don't applaud.

Sitting in groups of three -- NEWS TEAM from around the c remarkably similar in comparison...a great looking woman, looking man (either young or attractively avuncular) and or Hispanic.  They still APPLAUD -- not yet having graspe sincerity of Jane's plea which she presses with more urge
Please.  Don't!! (she yells)
I gathered these pieces as an example of what's
with local television news. The applause stops.

The excerpts from THREE SEPARATE SERIES on prostitution were SIMULTANEOUSLY broadcast by all stations in one city during sweeps week.  By what bend of either or suspension of duty is that broadcast news? She pauses half a beat for possible applause -- hearing n she continues.  An anchorman sneezes -- four people shout "gesundheit" simultaneously -- they laugh.
The legacy of Edward R. Murrow, Eric Sevareid, William Shirer, David Brinkley and Walter Cronkite is being squandered in a desperate popularity contest.  Our profession is in danger:
As Jane continues, REVEALING that the news team now have more in common.  They do not like Jane.

Yesterday's compliment has somehow managed to become today's kiss of death.  To be considered a serious journalist is no longer flattering. It presents the risk of being labeled ponderous, or worse yet, elitest,  right?
Women playing with their hair, young man bored...one middle-aged anchorman fusses with a spot on his tie...
Briefly departing from text.

All of you know what I'm talking about.   We're all trying to act together than  we are.  But we care.  So, we're all  secretly terrified, aren't we? Not a peep -- she is thrown but doggedly presses on with prepared speech though her throat constricts a bit, her v begins to rasp.

We are being increasingly influenced by the star system.  The network anchormen are so powerful they  compromise our last best hope.  The  current group is clearly qualified,  tied still to our best traditions, but  who follows these men?

Seated with other members of his news team, a young blond woman whose hand is resting on his inner leg, a good look Hispanic.  Tom feels a growing excitement -- Jane is not a speaker, she seems a savior.
Wow. His female colleague looks at him.
Oh, I've known so many women like that.  They don't like their looks so they're angry.
Fumbling with her cards, sunk but game -- gamer than she wish.
I was going to talk about other trends but... (mumbling)

...the magazine shows, news at profit, influence of Entertainment Tonight , the danger, the hope, the dream, the question...Oh, I was going to show you a tape -- a story that was carried by all networks on the same night -- the same night -- not one network noted a major policy change in Salt Two nuclear disarmament talks... Here's what they ran instead...Go ahead.  Show the tape.

Showing the Japanese Domino Championships as broadcast by networks in the Spring of 1985.  It is quite spectacular dominoes falling into one another provoking waves, crossi bridges, setting off little fireworks.  JANE'S AUDIENCE a loudly and squeals with delight.
Jane between the two monitors.  She begins to speak loudl the AUDIENCE NOISES of approval.
(loudly)
I know it's good film.  I know it's fun.  I like fun.  It's just not news. (as they continue to applaud)
Well, you're lucky you love it -- you're going to get a lot more just like it.
Jane sitting rocked into momentary catatonia, by the even Dazed as an animal stung by a tranquilizer dart.  She tak some irregular breaths waiting for normal life to return.

Tom the last person remaining in the room.  He approaches she is totally unaware of his presence, even when he casu mounts the stage with an athletic leap.  It takes courage Tom to fully intrude himself, which he now does:
Hello. She looks up at him.
Earnest, nervous -- handsome...Just when she needed a mir there it is.
Hi.
I just wanted to tell you  how great  you were.  My name's Tom Grunick.
(dumbly)
Thank you. (then)
They hated me.  I don't hate them.
Well, they say if you can reach even one person, it means something... And you did that. Jane looks up at his smile -- a beat then:
Would you like to have dinner with me?
Jane arrives at the maitre d' stand.  She has attempted t up to the extent that  packing for a short-day trip allow looks for Tom.  Tom rises from a table and is immediately her side.
Hi.  I was worried I was early.
I was a lot earlier. They are lead to a table and sit down.
I kept thinking what a great break it was for me to get to see you tonight.  More than a great break, maybe just what I needed...just when I needed it...Angel of mercy -- godsend...lifesaver...what?
(picking one)
I like "godsend."

I haven't been in news that long. I've just been looking for the right person to talk to.  I have about two thousand questions for you. He notices that her head has gone into her hands where it continues to rest.  He looks at her a beat.
It's possible now's not the right time. She lifts her head.
If we could just eat first.
Totally understood.  Totally wrong of me to talk shop after the day you've had.  Totally sorry.
Nooo.  If I could just have a roll, I'd be okay. She takes a roll from the roll plate.  He smiles at her. takes a bite.
Thank you.
As they walk along -- dumping occasionally and self-consc Jane is feeling a version of being turned on -- that is, adrift and temporarily free of obligations.  She is open making a memorable mistake.
Another thing I can't stand -- Is this dull? Tom shakes his head almost violently.
No, no, no, no... Jane looks at him curiously -- then:
(broadly)

Another thing I can't stand is ...when White House reporters bullshit with each other after a briefing and then one of them has a theory and the other quotes it in his story as "White House" sources say...
That actually goes on...
Yes.  My room is down here -- I'm not tired.  Do you want to keep talking?
Yes, sure.

A small good room -- her working paraphernalia very much evidence...the quality briefcase...the reams of well orga notes...the thick contact book -- Jane is sitting on the Tom, not far away in the room's only chair.  One lamp is and it serves to place Jane in the shadows and cast Tom i enormously flattering light.  MUSIC comes from her miniat portable STEREO system.
Come on...Even I'm not that hard on myself.
No, I really got this job on a fluke and wait till you hear where it ends up. Jane smiles a calming smile.
I was doing sports at the station. The newspaper ran this untrue story that I was leaving and they got all these tons of protest mail.  So they made me anchor.
So great -- right?
Except I'm no good at what I'm being a success at.

How are you at back rubs? Jane shifts her position so that her back is to Tom... He immobilized by the sudden turn.  Jane waits, just a bit l than it would take a man to run from the chair to her sid experiencing the ghost-like clutch of rejection.  She mov briskly past the moment -- grabbing a "good night" chocol from the pillow and munching it as she return to  his agenda.
It's sort of normal -- the way you feel.  In graduate school everyone thought the only mistake the admission committee made was letting them in. He moves to the bed.

Listen to me.  You keep on thinking I'm somebody ho lacks...confidence. That's not it.  I know I can talk well enough and I'm not bad at making contact with people, but I don't like the  feeling that I'm pretending to be a  reporter. (cont'd)
And half the time I don't really get  the news I'm talking about.  It isn't that I'm down on myself.  Trust me, I stink.
(levelly)
I trust you.
I didn't even have the chance to get really good at sports.  I wasn't bad. I thought I was starting to do interesting features but hockey is big at the station and...
(interrupting)
What about the obvious remedy? Reversing things.  Maybe getting a job on a newspaper.
I don't write. Jane laughs or, more accurately, scoffs as Tom Continues.
But that didn't stop me from sending out audition tapes to bigger stations and the networks.
Well, come on -- it is your life. Nobody is tying you to the fast track.  Did you go to college?
One year...almost one year.
So, you're not well educated and you have almost no experience and you can't write. He nods agreement.
And I'm making a fortune. Jane laughs very briefly -- then rubs her face vigorously her hands... He's making her feel a little crazy.  She ge the bed.
It's hard for me to advise you since you personify something that I truly think is dangerous.
Uh-huh.
(holding it in)
I agree with you -- you're not qualified. (letting it out)
So get qualified.  You can insist on being better prepared.  You don't have to just leave it as... (mimicking him)
'I don't write.  I'm not schooled. I don't understand the news I'm reading. But at least I'm upset about it, folks.' A beat, then he mumbles softly to himself.
Whoa, this was a mistake.
Just what do you want from me, anyway? Permission to be a fake?  Stop whining and do something about it. He gets up to leave.  She follows him.
Well, you don't have to start right now. He turns to her.
I hated the way you talked to me just now...and it wasn't just because you were right. He exits.
She is on the phone.
(into phone)
No.  It wasn't just the speech -- the same thing happened with this guy.  I have passed some line some place.  I am beginning to repel people I'm trying to seduce.
As he talks with Jane.
(agreeably)
He must have been great-looking, right?
Why do you say that?
Because nobody invites a bad- looking idiot to their bedroom. She smiles.
Okay.  Let's do me.
Sure.

Okay.  I feel like I'm slipping but do people who are actually slipping feel that way or is it always the really good people who are moving up who invariably think they're slipping because their standards are so high?
This conversation is not worthy of you.
I'd give anything if that were true.
(laughing)
Good night.
Wouldn't this be a great world if insecurity and desperation made us more attractive?  If needy were a turn-on?
Call if you get weird.
She hangs up -- pulls back the bedspread on the double be on the other half are papers, schedules -- tapes.  She do clear them off so that she is literally sleeping with her The PHONE RINGS.
(answering)
I was just thinking it was the shortest phone conversation we ever had.
A deserted well-lit area.  Tom on the phone.
I never told you the reason I was telling you everything for.
(pleasantly surprised it's him)
Hey?
Those audition tapes I sent out... I've been hired by your network for the Washington bureau.  So I'll probably see you at work.  Sorry. Jane is rocked and soured.
What???
Jane and Aaron walking to work -- agitated.
They didn't hire Peter Stiller from the  Times and he had a great audition tape.
You want to start going over who they could have gotten?  They can't take on people like this for network news.  For God's sake.  What's going on?
Tom arrives for first day of work.

ERNIE MERRIMAN is the network's Washington Bureau Chief. is in his early 60's, has worked for the network about 40 -- part of the golden age -- a family man, an honorable m a good guy.  Right now he is welcoming Tom to the network thereby good-naturedly helping with the destruction of al holds dear.  As he hands Tom his credentials:
Any particular area you feel strongest in?
To be honest, I was best at anchor. Ernie gives him a long look -- is he kidding?
Why don't you take a few days observing the system?  Then we'll put you on general assignment.

Two small TV monitors -- a smallish room.  Jane goes over timing notes which correspond to the time code SUPERED on monitors.  BOBBIE -- an extraordinarily silent man -- is Jane's bidding.  On the monitor we SEE the mercenary piec which Jane is editing against a tightening deadline.  The PHONE RINGS periodically -- Jane conducting abrupt conver which continuing to edit.  The pressure is palpable to be with but builds and builds; almost like a family fight ge out of hand and threatening to bend lives.  Through it al remains remarkable calm.  Her focus is amazing; her comma
(consulting notes)
Go back to 316, Bobbie.  The sound bite in the cab -- it starts, 'I don't know how I'll feel...'
We could...
(interrupting)

Please, Bobbie, we're pushing. As Bobbie expertly reverses the tape, Tom's face appears the glass doorway and then he enters the already crowded Jane's eyes click to him briefly.  She makes not a move t welcome him.  He pauses, but is committed and tries to fi a piece for himself against the wall.
They said I should observe the... Jane is distracted by the noise... Tom leaning over towar
They said it would be okay if...
(incredulous)
We're working here!!  You can stand over in the uh, uh, uh... She momentarily can't think of the word 'corner.'  Then b to Bobbie:
Play back the last line...
He said something about...
(sharply)

Let me hear it! Bobbie, taking the sharp commands with ever increasing, yet still repressed resentment. The Assistant Director, BLAIR LITTON, enters the editing She is about 26 and every night since she got her job as Assistant Director she has been the first to crack under
We'll need it in ten minutes.  We're putting it directly into... Jane holds up a finger of warning to Blair as she picks u ringing phone and talks to Bobbie at the same time.
(into phone)
Craig, just a second -- (to Bobbie)
Let me hear it! Through much of this chaos we focus on:

Wedged into an uncomfortable position between two tape ra He is wide-eyed at this circus of tension and fear.  His dart around constantly -- trying to take in as much as he always returning with wonder to focus on Jane.
(voice over)
It's been a long time since I've seen my folks and all but...I don't expect any big-deal homecoming.
Stop there. (into phone she's been holding)
I want to shoot a picture from a book I have in the office.
You don't have time.  Not a chance.
(into phone)
I'll be right down.  It's right tight. She crosses out.
I've got to tell Ernie...because there isn't enough time.
Yes, there is. Blair leaves, as Jane gathers up her notes.  She charges leaving Tom awkwardly along with Bobbie.
I'm Tom Grunick.  I started on General Assignment today. Bobbie stops the machine, turns in his chair and shakes h Then he smiles secretly and speaks his first full sentenc
I don't think she's going to make it. Tom exits.

Aaron is having a theoretical discussion with Ernie and JENNIFER MACK, a correspondent in her early 40's, a pione beauties in news.  She is well-schooled, bred, trained an known... GEORGE WEIN, a black correspondent in his 40s, a MARTIN KLEIN, formerly with the Johnson administration -- State Department correspondent for the network.
Okay, what about this?  Here's a tough ethical one.  Would you tell a source that you loved them just to get some information?
Yes.
Yes.
Me too.
Sure.
Jennifer didn't know there was an alternative. Jennifer laughs that laugh one always hopes beautiful wom will laugh when one says something funny.  Aaron smiles a
Here's one.  They allow us to have cameras at an execution in Florida. Do you broadcast tape of the guy  in the chair when they turn on the voltage?
Sure.
Why not?
Absolutely.
You bet.
Nothing like wrestling with a moral dilemma is there? Blair enters the scene, Tom trailing several feet behind, continuing to monitor the budding deadline crises.
Excuse me, Ernie, we're several minutes to air and Jane's shooting an insert still for tonight's piece.
She knows how much time she has. Blair flashes a tortured smile -- panic is growing.
Okay.  I just wanted you to know.
What is she shooting?
Norman Rockwell's 'Homecoming.'
(thinks then)
Oh, that's nice... (walking away)
We'll need some new lines.
Jane up against it now -- but still seemingly calm.  Tom watching, keeps on glancing at the clock fascinated, impressed.
Okay, Bobbie, just a two-second dissolve to the Rockwell.
Should I...
(interrupting)
Just a two-second dissolve.
(hurting)
Oh, Jesus, we have three minutes... Why do you do this to me.  Is it because I won an award?
Where Aaron is writing his last line on a folded over pie paper even as he gets ready to record.  He times it with stop watch.

Norman Rockwell's enduring portrait of a  Homecoming The return of a fighting man has always been one of the more moving ceremonies of war... Tearful women, proud men, excited children.  But J.D. Singer was right -- his homecoming was no big deal.
We have a minute and a half.  It's my responsibility to tell them we won't be ready.
Uh-uh.  We're be ready. Blair glances frantically at her watch.
In 84 seconds?
Sweeping from 28 minutes to -- 84 seconds from deadline. walks in, Jane looks up.
(hopefully)
Nine seconds.
Eleven and a half.
Oh, God.  Back it, Bobbie -- Bobbie?

head_text.subj: ALMOST SIMULTANEOUS DIALOGUE FOLLOWS. IT BUILDS UNTIL IT
DUPLICATE THE SOUND OF LOUD AND BAWDY SEX.

text: You're saying 'Oh, God..."  They are going to go to up and the screen will be black -- they're going to go to black because we're not there.  How about careers, huh?  How about careers?
42 seconds away.
We're not going to make it. Bobbie makes a small bobble -- Jane giving the merest evi of the strain, scratching her face repeatedly.
Whoops.
(unravelling)
Whoops?!?  Whoops?!?  No, please... no, ooh, ahhh, ohhh.
Shit, shit, shit...
(caught up)
You're almost there, you can do it -- can do -- can do. And as the pitch reaches its zenith, 27 seconds left.  Bo hands the tape to Blair.
Ready.
Blair hikes up her skirt and takes off.
